<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_alloc:
```c
static int lfs_dir_alloc(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_mdir_t *dir) {
    // allocate pair of dir blocks (backwards, so we write block 1 first)
    for (int i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
        int err = lfs_alloc(lfs, &dir->pair[(i+1)%2]);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    // zero for reproducibility in case initial block is unreadable
    dir->rev = 0;

    // rather than clobbering one of the blocks we just pretend
    // the revision may be valid
    int err = lfs_bd_read(lfs,
            NULL, &lfs->rcache, sizeof(dir->rev),
            dir->pair[0], 0, &dir->rev, sizeof(dir->rev));
    dir->rev = lfs_fromle32(dir->rev);
    if (err && err != LFS_ERR_CORRUPT) {
        return err;
    }

    // to make sure we don't immediately evict, align the new revision count
    // to our block_cycles modulus, see lfs_dir_compact for why our modulus
    // is tweaked this way
    if (lfs->cfg->block_cycles > 0) {
        dir->rev = lfs_alignup(dir->rev, ((lfs->cfg->block_cycles+1)|1));
    }

    // set defaults
    dir->off = sizeof(dir->rev);
    dir->etag = 0xffffffff;
    dir->count = 0;
    dir->tail[0] = LFS_BLOCK_NULL;
    dir->tail[1] = LFS_BLOCK_NULL;
    dir->erased = false;
    dir->split = false;

    // don't write out yet, let caller take care of that
    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no controlling expressions that are manifestly invariant and therefore requiring investigation under MISRA C:2023 Rule 14.3. Rationale for not flagging any fragments:

- for (int i = 0; i < 2; i++): The loop control expression i < 2 is not invariant because i is modified each iteration (i++). This is a well-formed finite loop, not an invariant controlling expression.

- if (err) and if (err && err != LFS_ERR_CORRUPT): Both use the variable err which is assigned immediately prior (from lfs_alloc in the loop or from lfs_bd_read before the second check). These conditions are not compile-time constants nor invariant within their execution context and therefore are not violations.

- if (lfs->cfg->block_cycles > 0): This tests a configuration field. Although the configuration value may be constant at runtime, the expression is not a compile-time constant and is evaluated once here as a normal selection—this is not the kind of invariant controlling expression that Rule 14.3 targets (which is primarily concerned with loop/selection controls that cannot change and thus lead to unintended infinite/empty behaviour). In addition, the rule provides explicit exceptions for legitimate infinite loops and certain do-while constant expressions; neither applies here.

No other iteration or selection statements are present that evaluate a manifestly invariant expression. Therefore there are no code fragments that need further investigation for Rule 14.3 in this function.
